A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces.

Don't hesitate to give detail, or describe particular events. If they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, but may be answered by anyone who has personal experiences of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.
PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the reader answering this questionnaire.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Don't hesitate to give details if there is not sufficient space to answer the question.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1921, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

1. Your full name: John Smith
2. Your address: 376 McCallum Rd, Virginia
3. Date: March 25th, 1984
4. Occupation: Teacher
5. What was your father's occupation? (Please write in detail)
   William Brown - Teacher
6. When did you move to British Columbia? (Please write in detail)
   October 1989
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to British Columbia.
   Victoria, British Columbia
8. How old were you when you first came to British Columbia? (Please be as specific as possible)
   I was 17 years old when I came to British Columbia.
9. What were your reasons for coming to British Columbia?
   I liked the mountains and life there. We also study nature and people through reading and people.
10. How did you hear about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Television or government information?)
1. Your full name: John Smith
2. Your address: 356 Main Street, Metallurgical Village
3. Date: March 20, 1954
4. What was your occupation? (Please write out completely.)
   - Teacher, School District
5. When did you move to South Carolina? (Please write out completely.)
   - October 1989
6. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to South Carolina.
   - Ontario, Victoria

7. How old were you when you first came to South Carolina? (Please write out completely.)
   - 24

8. What were your reasons for moving here?
   - I liked the weather and the life. Also, I love nature studies.

9. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people, reading about it, etc.)
   - Through reading and people.

10. What do you think about the West? (Through other people, reading about it, etc.)
    - I think it's beautiful and peaceful.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?
They thought that I was coming to be a country.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
With a party

13. What means of transportation did you use?
By train

14. What incidents of the journey best do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)
The weatherman threw my trunk out of the train, and the contents scattered all over. There was not much flatware there.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
The Waverley Hotel

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
Laird, near the old Regina Hospital

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.
The Almudena and 79 A.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?
One of the Oldest Telegraphers in Canada. Red Roadway, farming and real estate.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

They thought that I was coming to Canada.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

With a party.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

By train.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

The breakdown through and wreck out of the train and the contents scattered all over. There was not much flatware there.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

The Waverley Hotel.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

In Medicine Hat, Alberta.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

The Klondyke and B.C.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?

I worked in the telegraph office and then in the railway office in Edmonton, farming and real estate.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

Occasionally.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

Older than you (first wife)

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

My brothers.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

We settled near me.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

My trip to the Plandale where I spent seven years.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? By what means of travel?

With own and horse.

Regina - Saskatchewan

   - Regina - 30 miles

   - Yes and also at Winnipeg

   - Once a week, twice for the new ones introduced.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?
   - New forty years ago.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues?

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?
   - I bought a telephone for myself.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
   - You
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1924? What reasons did they have for moving?

Not many.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930s? Did many return?

More than half. Some returned.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organization, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

My brother was an active in church affairs.
